In Persia and in the Persian Gulf, gypsum is used as a cementing material. Its softness prevents its being used as a paving material, but it is widely used in the manufacture of plaster board for the lining of houses and such purposes. It can also be utilised for the manufacture of plaster of Paris or as a surface dressing in agriculture. 2. It is to be found in large quantities throughout the Persian Gulf. There are considerable quantities of rock gypsum along the Persian coast:in the Pars series, especially in the neighbourhood of JNaband and also between Lingah and Bandar Abbas. It is also to be found in the Hormuz Islands, though here it has got mixed with other substances and as a result would be more difficult to extract. There are, however, valuable deposits at Bu Musa and Halul. A somewhat impure form known as earthy gypsum is found in the Hormuz Islands and Bahrein. At the latter place the deposit is sufficiently deep and sufficiently pure to be useful.•• 3. The more valuable deposits are undoubtedly within Persian territory and presumably the present proposal to interest a British firm in the exploitation of gypsum is not intended to include (A* ou vA. these Persian deposits. It wrU. appear however from the information above, which is based upon Pilgrim’s X report, that valuable concessions might be obtained in Bu Musa, Halul or Bahrein. 4. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 23; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. A previous foliation sequence, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: The file concerns the potential commercial exploitation by British firms of deposits of gypsum in the Persian Gulf. Gypsum was used as a cementing material and for the manufacture of plaster board. The main deposits were along the coast of Iran (referred to throughout as Persia), but the substance was also more widely distributed in the region.The issue is discussed by British officials in response to an enquiry by the British firm Frank C. Strick and Company. A letter from the Foreign Office expresses the view that there was no reason to discourage such commercial activity in Bahrain or any Arab territory where there was no risk of disputes over sovereignty between the British and Iranian Governments. A letter from the Board of Trade recommends that only 'perfunctory encouragement' should be given to the firm, given the fact that gypsum was available in large quantities in various parts of the world, and this latter approach was adopted by the India Office.The papers are mainly dated 1935-36. There are no papers in the file dated 1937-44.The file includes a divider, which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
